results.name: Reconstructing reality
results.description: While documentary pertains to be about the truth, many filmmakers and artists have used ingenious reconstructions to represent an abstracted honesty.

key_work.title: Drifters
key_work.brief_description: The only film ever directed personally by John Grierson, this documentary was made for the Empire Marketing Board about the men on the British herring fleets, which employed montage and documentary techniques to demonstrate the human side of the fishing industry.

constellations_primary.name: Reconstructing reality
constellations_primary.description: While documentary pertains to be about the truth, many filmmakers and artists have used ingenious reconstructions to represent an abstracted honesty.

start.title: The Thin Blue Line
start.creator_credit: Errol Morris and Mark Lipson
start.brief_description: Errol Morris’s unique documentary dramatically re-enacts the crime scene and investigation of a police officer’s murder in Dallas in a film that the Criterion Collection describes as “a work of meticulous journalism and gripping drama”.

constellations_primary.name: Presumption of guilt
constellations_primary.description: A Constellation looking at true crime documentaries, the nature of innocence and prejudice.

constellations_other.name: Reasonable doubt
constellations_other.description: Factual media has the power to reframe information and put forth new, persuasive arguments.  For the criminal justice system, where convictions are made based on arguments being convincing beyond a reasonable doubt, True Crime media has the ability to create doubt, right the wrongs of the justice system, and shed new light on closed cases.

constellations_other.name: Reconstructing reality
constellations_other.description: While documentary pertains to be about the truth, many filmmakers and artists have used ingenious reconstructions to represent an abstracted honesty.

end.title: Waltz with Bashir
end.creator_credit: Gerhard Meixner, Roman Paul, Serge Lalou, Yael Nahlieli and Ari Folman
end.brief_description: Director and Israeli army veteran Ari Folman interviews friends and former soldiers about their memories of the 1982 Lebanon war, especially the Sabra and Shatila massacre in Beirut. He uses animation to illustrate the personal memories and dreams of his interview subjects.

constellations_other.name: Reconstructing reality
constellations_other.description: While documentary pertains to be about the truth, many filmmakers and artists have used ingenious reconstructions to represent an abstracted honesty.

links.description: Reconstruction is used with a difference in Ari Folman’s Waltz with Bashir, which uses a dream-like animation style to reconstruct the director’s experience as a soldier in the 1982 Lebanon War from a unique documentary perspective.

start.title: Land Without Bread
start.creator_credit: Luis Buñuel and Ramón Acín
start.brief_description: A surrealistic documentary portrait of the region of Las Hurdes, a remote region of Spain where civilisation has barely developed, showing how the local peasants try to survive without even the most basic utilities and skills.

constellations_other.name: Reconstructing reality
constellations_other.description: While documentary pertains to be about the truth, many filmmakers and artists have used ingenious reconstructions to represent an abstracted honesty.

links.description: Not only did Errol Morris’ seminal crime documentary also stage scenes, but it popularised the use of highly stylised reconstructions in true crime TV shows and docuseries, which are now a trademark of the genre.

end.title: The Act of Killing
end.creator_credit: Christine Cynn, Joshua Oppenheimer, Anne Köhncke, Joram ten Brink, Michael Uwemedimo and Signe Byrge Sørensen
end.headline_credit: Denmark, Indonesia, Norway and United Kingdom, 2012
end.brief_description: In a place where killers are celebrated as heroes, these filmmakers challenge unrepentant death-squad leaders to dramatize their role in genocide. The result is a surreal, cinematic journey, not only into the memories and imaginations of mass murderers, but also into a frighteningly banal regime of corruption and impunity.

constellations_other.name: Reconstructing reality
constellations_other.description: While documentary pertains to be about the truth, many filmmakers and artists have used ingenious reconstructions to represent an abstracted honesty.

links.description: In this haunting documentary about participants in the Indonesian mass killings of 1965–66, perpetrators recreate their experiences in the style of their favorite film genres, blurring the line between fact and fiction, in what director Joshua Oppenheimer called “a documentary of imagination”.

start.title: Drifters
start.brief_description: The only film ever directed personally by John Grierson, this documentary was made for the Empire Marketing Board about the men on the British herring fleets, which employed montage and documentary techniques to demonstrate the human side of the fishing industry.

links.description: Scottish filmmaker John Grierson coined the term documentary, but in The Drifters he used fictional filmmaking techniques and staged scenes. Likewise, Luis Buñuel took a surrealist approach to his study of people living around La Alberca in Spain and also staged scenes.

results.name: When music speaks
results.description: Some characters or moments are expressed more intensely through a musical motif than dialogue or action.

key_work.title: The Piano
key_work.headline_credit: Aotearoa / New Zealand, Australia and France, 1993
key_work.brief_description: The piano used in Jane Campion’s award-winning classic dates from 1825–30 and was shipped to the New Zealand from London. Two replicas were made – a lightweight version that could be carried through the bush and one with a steel frame for underwater scenes.

constellations_other.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_other.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

start.title: Paris, Texas
start.creator_credit: Anatole Dauman, Don Guest, Wim Wenders and Road Movies
start.headline_credit: France, Germany, United Kingdom and United States of America, 1984

video_links.name: PARIS, TEXAS Trailer (1984) - The Criterion Collection

start.brief_description: Travis Henderson (Harry Dean Stanton) wanders out of the desert not knowing who he is in Wim Wenders’ Palme d’Or-winning film. Henderson’s brother, Walt (Dean Stockwell) finds him, and helps to recover the memory of the life Travis led before he walked out on his family and disappeared four years earlier.

end.title: The Gospel According to Matthew
end.creator_credit: Alfredo Bini

video_links.name: The Gospel According to Matthew (1964) - trailer

end.brief_description: Italian enfant terrible filmmaker Pier Paolo Pasolini interprets the Gospel of Matthew to portray Jesus Christ as a proto-Marxist, taking dialogue directly from the book in the Bible in a film considered to be one of the best on Jesus’ life by the Vatican.

constellations_other.name: When music speaks

links.description: The main theme of the Paris, Texas is based on Blind Willie Johnson’s “Dark was the Night, Cold was the Ground”. The lyrics, are about the Crucifixion, which is featured in Pablo Pasolini’s The Gospel According to St Mathew.

links.description: Like Ada in The Piano, only to comic effect, Harpo Marx did not speak while in character as one of the Marx Brothers. In A Day at the Races, he begins playing a piano, only to pull out the strings and use them as a harp!

start.title: Super Mario Bros.
start.brief_description: In 1985, Nintendo introduced the world to one of the most iconic and endearing videogame characters of all time, Mario. Well, Super Mario to you. The red overall-wearing plumber bounced his way into history and pop culture consciousness in the first of many videogames.

constellations_other.name: Representation of women in videogames
constellations_other.description: Ms Pac-Man is the first famous female game protagonist, but let's face it – she's just Pac-Man with a bow. This Constellation looks at the history of female representation in videogames.

end.title: Jaws
end.creator_credit: David Brown and Richard D. Zanuck
end.brief_description: Steven Spielberg created the summer blockbuster with this holiday horror that snapped up more tickets at the box office than the great white shark did swimmers in the waters of Amity Island. Featuring one of cinema’s greatest villains and scores, it changed the movie-going landscape forever.

constellations_other.name: Hiding in plain sight
constellations_other.description: This print of upside-down heads is an early optical illusion featuring hidden characters. Movie studios have continued the tradition of playing with perspective in the bold designs, vivid colours and hidden meanings of film posters.

links.description: While the Super Mario Bros. theme invokes memories of happy adrenaline, John William’s iconic shark theme in Jaws put a shiver down the spines of a generation of film-goers.

end.title: Psycho
end.creator_credit: Alfred Hitchcock
end.brief_description: When real estate clerk Marion Crane goes on the lam with a wad of cash, she ends up at the notorious Bates Motel, where manager Norman Bates cares for his housebound mother. All seems okay, until Marion decides to take a shower…

constellations_other.name: Good vibrations
constellations_other.description: Since its invention, the humble theremin has been used in a number of different ways to evoke all sorts of strange sounds and moods.

constellations_other.name: The drama and nuance of silhouette
constellations_other.description: Ali Gumillya Baker uses silhouette to evocative effect in her work reimagining the colonial gaze. The lighting technique has long been employed by filmmakers for its ability to dramatically convey a wide variety of emotions in everything from film noir to animation and whimsy.

constellations_other.name: Painting pictures
constellations_other.description: Painter and photographer Louis Le Prince was inspired to develop the technology to make animated pictures by the circular panoramic paintings of his friends. His films captured everyday life and alluded to his artistic vision for cinema.

links.description: The repetitive, deep sawing sound created by Williams recalls Bernard Herrmann’s stabbing strings in the infamous shower scene from Hitchcock’s Psycho. Both are two of pop culture’s most terrifying sounds.

results.name: Transformations
results.description: Like many techniques born from the visual language of magic lanterns, the dissolve effect was incorporated into filmmaking and is still used today.

start.title: Powers of Ten
start.brief_description: The Eamses film shows a linear view of our universe – first from the human scale to the sea of galaxies, then directly down to the nucleus of a carbon atom. With images, narration and a distance register, it gives a clue to the relative size of things.

links.description: Computer technology gave the dissolve technique new life and allowed for more elaborate uses. Directed by John Landis, “Black or White” has a sequence where people of different races, nationalities and genders morph into one another.

end.title: The Wolf Man
end.creator_credit: George Waggner
end.brief_description: Ancient curses, fortune tellers and one of the most iconic movie monsters ever feature in Universal Pictures’ The Wolfman. After Larry Talbot (Lon Chaney Jr) returns home for his brother’s funeral, he’s bitten by a werewolf and transforms into a creature of the night.

constellations_other.name: Transformations
constellations_other.description: Like many techniques born from the visual language of magic lanterns, the dissolve effect was incorporated into filmmaking and is still used today.

links.description: Dissolving magic lantern slides showed the gradual transition from one projected image to another like landscapes dissolving from day to night. The Wolf Man used dissolves to depict Lon Chaney Jr’s character Larry Talbot transformation from man into beast.

end.title: The Simpsons
end.brief_description: Set in Springfield, the average American town, the show focuses on the antics and everyday adventures of the Simpson family; Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa and Maggie, as well as a virtual cast of thousands. Since the beginning, the series has been a pop culture icon, attracting hundreds of celebrities to guest star. The show has also made name for itself in its fearless satirical take on politics, media and American life in general.

constellations_other.name: Migrations
constellations_other.description: Universal Everything's Migrations features fantastical creatures born from elements of other animals, just like the titles in this Constellation.

constellations_other.name: Oh, no! Beta!
constellations_other.description: The Sony Betacam BVP-3P was a broadcast-quality camera that used Sony's Beta system, most commonly found in consumer cameras. During the Format Wars in the 1970s and 80s, Beta lost to the cheaper and more accessible Video Home System (VHS).

constellations_other.name: Transformations
constellations_other.description: Like many techniques born from the visual language of magic lanterns, the dissolve effect was incorporated into filmmaking and is still used today.

constellations_other.name: Cartoon classics and criticism
constellations_other.description: A whole cavalcade of cartoons have successfully made the leap into arcades and onto consoles, but the relationship between cinema and videogames is far more likely to fizzle out.

constellations_other.name: Nadia Tass
constellations_other.description: Comedic and cult classics take centre stage in Nadia Tass' career.

links.description: In the 2004 episode, “The Ziff Who Came to Dinner”, the opening couch gag zoomes out from the couch into the galaxy only to end back in the couch, referencing Powers of Ten.

results.name: Analogue and digital film
results.description: Though technology has evolved since celluloid film strips were invented, contemporary filmmakers and artists still appreciate and celebrate the analogue in a digital world.

key_work.title: Film strips
key_work.brief_description: What are the most commonly used film guages? 35mm is the standard; 16mm and 8mm are favoured by amateur filmmakers; and the wide, high-resolution 70mm is most commonly used for epics by Hollywood directors.

end.title: Inglourious Basterds
end.creator_credit: Henning Molfenter and Lawrence Bender
end.headline_credit: Germany and United States of America, 2009
end.brief_description: In Nazi-occupied France during World War II, a group of Jewish-American soldiers known as “The Basterds” are chosen specifically to spread fear throughout the Third Reich by scalping and brutally killing Nazis.

constellations_other.name: Splicing history and silencing the lambs
constellations_other.description: With plastic strips coated with light-sensitive emulsions, film strips captured light and created moving pictures. In this Constellation we trace celluloid and splicing as plot device to serial killers, secrets agents and Super 8.

constellations_other.name: Analogue and digital film
constellations_other.description: Though technology has evolved since celluloid film strips were invented, contemporary filmmakers and artists still appreciate and celebrate the analogue in a digital world.

constellations_other.name: Movies in movies in a movie museum
constellations_other.description: The 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector used the first electric light ever invented, which was perfectly suited for movie projectors. This Constellation explores the movies where characters go to the movies, by two movie-obsessed directors.

links.description: Celluloid is the material used to create the first mass-produced motion pictures. Notoriously flammable and prone to combustion, celluloid film was iconically weaponised in the climax of Quentin Tarantino’s Inglorious Basterds.

constellations_other.description: Though technology has evolved since celluloid film strips were invented, contemporary filmmakers and artists still appreciate and celebrate the analogue in a digital world.

constellations_other.name: Movies in movies in a movie museum
constellations_other.description: The 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector used the first electric light ever invented, which was perfectly suited for movie projectors. This Constellation explores the movies where characters go to the movies, by two movie-obsessed directors.

end.title: Side by Side
end.creator_credit: Justin Szlasa and Keanu Reeves
end.brief_description: Keanu Reeves explores the development of cinema and the impact of digital filmmaking via in-depth interviews with Hollywood masters, such as James Cameron, David Fincher, David Lynch, Christopher Nolan, Martin Scorsese, George Lucas, Steven Soderbergh, and many more.

constellations_other.name: Analogue and digital film
constellations_other.description: Though technology has evolved since celluloid film strips were invented, contemporary filmmakers and artists still appreciate and celebrate the analogue in a digital world.

links.description: Quentin Tarantino continues to champion using traditional film stock, while most filmmakers use digital cameras and projectors. Side By Side documents the respective histories of analogue and digital film, with many filmmakers, including Tarantino, giving their opinions on the two formats.

end.brief_description: Orphaned except for an uncle, Hugo Cabret lives in the walls of a train station in 1930s Paris. His job is to oil and maintain the station’s clocks, but he’s more interested in protecting a broken automaton and notebook left to him by his late father.

constellations_other.name: The Lumière brothers
constellations_other.description: The Lumière brothers understood the potential of cinema to be exhibited theatrically. Only one person could watch films through Thomas Edison's Kinetograph, while Auguste and Louis exhibited their films to thousands with Cinematographe.

constellations_other.name: Innovation, technology and design: Edweard Muybridge
constellations_other.description: A focus on the discovery, inspiration and innovation at the heart of moving image history

constellations_other.name: Analogue and digital film
constellations_other.description: Though technology has evolved since celluloid film strips were invented, contemporary filmmakers and artists still appreciate and celebrate the analogue in a digital world.

links.description: Martin Scorsese is a film legend who has embraced digital filmmaking. After Avatar (2009) spawned a 3D film resurgence, Scorsese’s Hugo was one of the first films shot in digital 3D format. While it uses digital techniques, it’s a love letter to the early days of analogue filmmaking.

end.brief_description: Harry Graham and his wife Eve are adopting a child. When PI Jordan uncovers that Graham has another wife and a small child in LA, he confesses. In flashback, Graham recounts the strains in his marriage and how he fell for the kind-hearted Phyllis.

links.description: Martin Scorsese founded The Film Foundation, which is dedicated to preserving motion picture history, including Ida Lupino’s The Bigamist (1953). Lupino was a trailblazer for women in the film industry, and The Bigamist was the first film that she both starred in and directed.

end.brief_description: ‘Anywhere Out of the World’ (2000) is part of No Ghost Just a Shell (1999-2003), a project born in collaboration with the artist Pierre Huyghe that explores the relationship between forms of producing, distributing and perceiving artworks.

links.description: Hugo features an automaton, an antique machine that’s programmed to perform an activity like drawing. Philippe Parreno’s artworks explore similar emulations of real life, featuring a stock character purchased by Parreno, who in ‘Anywhere Out of the World’ hauntingly reflects on being a digital puppet.

results.name: Boom mics, Clara Bow and musicals
results.description: The microphone was called the "terror of the studios" when sound films were introduced in the late 1920s, but after initial resistance Hollywood fully embraced the new technology.

key_work.title: Dorothy Arzner and the boom mic
key_work.brief_description: Director Dorothy Arzner had a problem on the set of The Wild Party (1929). Her lead actress, silent-era ‘It’ girl Clara Bow, couldn’t perform energetically with the new microphones. To let her move freely, Arzner created the first boom mic.

constellations_other.name: Directions of storytelling
constellations_other.description: Panoramic slides gave magic lanternists the ability to progress narratives by adjusting slides left or right. This movement is emblematic of a panning shot where the camera follows the action the natural way your head moves.

links.description: The Artist was promoted as the first silent film to win the Best Picture Oscar since Wings (1927), which coincidentally starred Clara Bow. Technically though, because of small sound snippets, The Artist was a ‘part-talkie’, a hybrid film that bridged the transition from silent to talkies.

end.title: Aotearoa (New Zealand) Diorama
end.credit_line:
Edie Kurzer, Australia, 2020

Flight of the Concords babushka dolls

Irene Hwang, Australia, 2019

Cinema chair from the Barkly Theatre in Footscray
end.brief_description: It could be hobbits traversing through Middle Earth or Lucy Lawless reshaping the world with her sword: either way, the New Zealand film and television scene loves genre. This passion has seen our friends across the Tasman celebrated globally for their unique and inventive vision, whether that’s Peter Jackson morphing from Meet The Feebles (1989) to the epic The Lord Of The Rings trilogy (2001-03), or Taika Waititi’s simultaneously dark and playful vision in Hunt For The Wilderpeople (2016). From Flight Of The Conchords (2007-09) to Xena: Warrior Princess (1995-2001) the Kiwi film industry has consistently created a distinct niche in the global screen world.

start.title: World of Warcraft
start.brief_description:
Four years have passed since the aftermath of Warcraft III: Reign of Chaos, and a great tension now smolders throughout the ravaged world of Azeroth. As the battle-worn races begin to rebuild their shattered kingdoms, new threats, both ancient and ominous, arise to plague the world once again. World of Warcraft is an online role-playing experience set in the award-winning Warcraft universe. Players assume the roles of Warcraft heroes as they explore, adventure, and quest across a vast world. Being “Massively Multiplayer,” World of Warcraft allows thousands of players to interact within the same world. Whether adventuring together or fighting against each other in epic battles, players will form friendships, forge alliances, and compete with enemies for power and glory. A dedicated live team will create a constant stream of new adventures to undertake, lands to explore, and monsters to vanquish. This content ensures that the game will never be the same from month to month, and will continue to offer new challenges and adventures for years to come.

This game has a monthly online fee. Adventure together with thousands of other players simultaneously. Explore an expansive world with miles of forests, deserts, snow-blown mountains, and other exotic lands. Join the Horde or the Alliance as one of 8 playable races. Select from 9 classes, including holy Paladins, shape-shifting Druids, powerful Warriors and Mages, demon-summoning Warlocks, and more. Encounter many familiar and new Warcraft characters and monsters. Learn the continuing story of Azeroth by completing a wide variety of challenging quests. Journey through an epic world filled with dungeons of different styles and depths. Explore 6 huge capital cities, which serve as major hubs for the races inhabiting them. Practice various trade skills to help locate reagents, make and enhance custom items, acquire wealth through trade with other players, and more. Purchase tickets for travel along a number of air routes flown by creatures such as Gryphons and Wyverns. For global transportation, travel by Boat or Goblin Zeppelin. Once a certain level has been achieved, players can choose to purchase permanent personal mounts, such as Dire Wolves and Horses. Establish a guild, purchase a custom guild tabard, and promote or demote recruits to different ranks within the guild. Locate and engage other players with easy-to-use features and tools, including chat channels, friends lists, and animated and audible character expressions. Customize the game’s interface via XML. Enjoy hundreds of hours of gameplay with new quests, items, and adventures every month.

end.title: Leeeeeerooooooy Jenkins!
end.creator_credit: J Jameson
end.material_description: Screen recording of J Jonah Jameson's YouTube channel
end.brief_description:
In 2005, a World of Warcraft player character Leeroy Jenkins (played by Ben Schulz) became an internet legend. While his team carefully planned a battle, Leeroy – who was AFK (away from keyboard) making chicken – charged in shouting his own name. Chaos followed. This viral moment spread beyond the game and still make the rounds on TikTok today. Blizzard officially added Leeroy as a non-playable character, a card, and even an achievement. His name became shorthand for recnkless bravery (or foolishness).

It was later revealed that the viral moment was staged by a group of friends – but the fact it’s still being spoken about 20 years later stands testament to its legacy.

links.description: Perhaps one of the most recogniseable moments in World of Warcraft came during a raid in 2005. As his friends meticulously planned their attack, Leeroy Jenkins was making chicken. When he returned, and charged into battle, a meme was born.

end.title: World of Warcraft
end.brief_description:
Four years have passed since the aftermath of Warcraft III: Reign of Chaos, and a great tension now smolders throughout the ravaged world of Azeroth. As the battle-worn races begin to rebuild their shattered kingdoms, new threats, both ancient and ominous, arise to plague the world once again. World of Warcraft is an online role-playing experience set in the award-winning Warcraft universe. Players assume the roles of Warcraft heroes as they explore, adventure, and quest across a vast world. Being “Massively Multiplayer,” World of Warcraft allows thousands of players to interact within the same world. Whether adventuring together or fighting against each other in epic battles, players will form friendships, forge alliances, and compete with enemies for power and glory. A dedicated live team will create a constant stream of new adventures to undertake, lands to explore, and monsters to vanquish. This content ensures that the game will never be the same from month to month, and will continue to offer new challenges and adventures for years to come.

This game has a monthly online fee. Adventure together with thousands of other players simultaneously. Explore an expansive world with miles of forests, deserts, snow-blown mountains, and other exotic lands. Join the Horde or the Alliance as one of 8 playable races. Select from 9 classes, including holy Paladins, shape-shifting Druids, powerful Warriors and Mages, demon-summoning Warlocks, and more. Encounter many familiar and new Warcraft characters and monsters. Learn the continuing story of Azeroth by completing a wide variety of challenging quests. Journey through an epic world filled with dungeons of different styles and depths. Explore 6 huge capital cities, which serve as major hubs for the races inhabiting them. Practice various trade skills to help locate reagents, make and enhance custom items, acquire wealth through trade with other players, and more. Purchase tickets for travel along a number of air routes flown by creatures such as Gryphons and Wyverns. For global transportation, travel by Boat or Goblin Zeppelin. Once a certain level has been achieved, players can choose to purchase permanent personal mounts, such as Dire Wolves and Horses. Establish a guild, purchase a custom guild tabard, and promote or demote recruits to different ranks within the guild. Locate and engage other players with easy-to-use features and tools, including chat channels, friends lists, and animated and audible character expressions. Customize the game’s interface via XML. Enjoy hundreds of hours of gameplay with new quests, items, and adventures every month.

key_work.title: Théâtre Optique
key_work.brief_description: In 1892, two years after developing the praxinoscope theatre, Charles-Émile Reynaud debuted his grandest invention – the Théâtre Optique – in Paris. This device projected moving pictures that had been hand-painted onto flexible, coloured, regularly perforated strips of gelatine crystalloid.

start.brief_description: 9 to 5 is an office satire about three female secretaries who decide to get revenge on their tyrannical, sexist boss by abducting him and running the business themselves. Features star turns by Jane Fonda, Lily Tomlin and Dolly Parton.

end.title: Workout
end.brief_description: Jane Fonda’s Workout is the original VHS workout program. The program includes a 30 minute beginners’ class and a 60 minute advanced session. Fond would go on to release 23 different home workout videos and sell more than 17 million copies.

constellations_other.name: Technology and work
constellations_other.description: How does the godfather of animation and sprocket technology connect to Jane Fonda workout videos and a Jesus biopic?

links.description: Jane Fonda not only co-starred in 9 to 5 but originated and steered the project through her production company IPC Films. Two years later, the first of her Jane Fonda’s Workout videos sold more than a million copies on the relatively new home VHS format.

start.title: Workers Leaving the Lumière Factory
start.creator_credit: Auguste Lumière, Louis Lumière and Lumière
start.brief_description: The film La Sortie des Usines Lumière à Lyon (Workers Leaving the Lumière Factory in Lyon, 1895) by the Lumière brothers is 45 seconds long and is considered one of the first motion pictures ever made.

constellations_other.name: Technology and work
constellations_other.description: How does the godfather of animation and sprocket technology connect to Jane Fonda workout videos and a Jesus biopic?

end.brief_description: In this documentary essay based on the Lumière brothers groundbreaking film, Harun Farocki uses to provide an insight into the changes both in work and film through motion pictures of workers leaving factories across the years.

constellations_other.name: Technology and work
constellations_other.description: How does the godfather of animation and sprocket technology connect to Jane Fonda workout videos and a Jesus biopic?

links.description: One hundred years after the Lumière brothers’ first film, German artist Harun Farocki revisited its themes in Arbeiter verlassen die Fabrik, expanding the Lumière’s 45-second home movie into a 37-minute cinematic essay on politics and industrial power.

links.description: Unlike Farocki’s sober and rigorous cinematic essay, the 1980 Hollywood comedy 9 to 5 also examined workplace politics but grossed more than $100 million at the box office by exploiting the theme as popular entertainment.

links.description: The 1979 film Jesus lost $2 million on its cinema release. But thanks to the same VHS technology exploited by Jane Fonda it was distributed internationally in more than 1,000 languages and has been watched by an estimated 3 billion people.

start.title: Théâtre Optique

end.creator_credit: Auguste Lumière, Louis Lumière and Lumière

constellations_other.name: Technology and work

links.description: In 1888, Charles-Émile Reynaud patented the Théâtre Optique, which featured film perforation and sprocket technology. The Lumière brothers had studied Reynaud’s invention and in 1895, patented their “cinematographe”, an early camera-projector that advanced this technology, and produced La Sortie de l’Usine Lumière à Lyon.

start.title: Evil Angels
start.creator_credit: Verity Lambert
start.headline_credit: Australia and United States of America, 1988
start.brief_description: Based on the true story of Lindy Chamberlain who, during a family camping trip to Ayers Rock in central Australia, claimed she witnessed a dingo take her baby daughter, Azaria, from their tent. Azaria’s body was never found and, after investigations and two public inquests, she is charged with murder.

end.title: Conversations with a Killer: The Ted Bundy Tapes
end.creator_credit: Sara Enright

video_links.name: Conversations with a Killer: The Ted Bundy Tapes | Official Trailer [HD] | Netflix

end.brief_description: A unique look inside the mind of an infamous serial killer with this cinematic self-portrait crafted from statements made by Ted Bundy, including present-day interviews, archival footage and audio recordings from death row.

constellations_other.name: Dial M for Media
constellations_other.description: Explores the nature of media use in high-profile cases as well as the ability of media to sway public minds.

links.description:
The case of Azaria Chamberlain has since been used as an example of how media sensationalism and bias can influence a case. The findings of the inquest were broadcast live on television—a first in Australia.

The trial of Ted Bundy, one of America’s most notorious serial killers, was the first ever case to be televised nationally in the US. Conversely to Ramsey and Chamberlain, Bundy was, and still is, portrayed as charming and handsome in media. He was often described as “Kennedyesque” and “All-American”.

end.title: Hearts and Minds
end.creator_credit: Peter Davis
end.brief_description: Many times during his presidency, Lyndon B. Johnson said that ultimate victory in the Vietnam War depended upon the U.S. military winning the “hearts and minds” of the Vietnamese people. Filmmaker Peter Davis uses Johnson’s phrase in an ironic context in this anti-war documentary.

constellations_other.name: Dial M for Media
constellations_other.description: Explores the nature of media use in high-profile cases as well as the ability of media to sway public minds.

links.description: The Vietnam conflict is largely considered the first ever televised war as many reporters were able to report on the realities of war first hand. This increased news coverage offered some of the first footage Americans would see of the war and is often attributed to undermining public support of the conflict. Hearts and Minds was released during the conflict and is a polarizing film that reviewers call either a masterpiece of political/documentary filmmaking or anti-war propaganda.

end.title: Orwell: Ignorance is Strength
end.brief_description: Step into the shoes of a government official in a top-secret department of the Orwell surveillance program. Given the power to both uncover and fabricate “the truth”, how far will you go in the service of your country? Season 2 of Orwell, the award-winning surveillance thriller.

constellations_other.name: Dial M for Media
constellations_other.description: Explores the nature of media use in high-profile cases as well as the ability of media to sway public minds.

links.description: The game Orwell is hugely political and comments heavily on the power of media in influencing public opinion. In the game you have access to the use of an “Influencer” tool allowing you to create fabricated narratives you can leak on to social media, mainly through “Blabber”, the game’s equivalent of Twitter. Through this the player can spread a story that destroys public opinion on topics and the reputation of influential people who oppose the government.

end.title: American Experience

video_links.name: American Experience: The Great War: Transformed

end.brief_description: TV’s most-watched history series brings to life the compelling stories from our past that inform our understanding of the world today.

constellations_other.name: Dial M for Media
constellations_other.description: Explores the nature of media use in high-profile cases as well as the ability of media to sway public minds.

links.description:
Perhaps one of the most interesting examples of the power of the media is the 1938 radio broadcast of Orson Welles, War of the Worlds based on the novel of the same name by H.G Wells. The program has become famous for supposedly fooling its listeners into believing that a Martian invasion was actually taking place prompting claims of panic and mass hysteria.

Episode 290 “War of the Worlds” of popular show American Experience recounts and examines the impact of the infamous broadcast.

start.creator_credit: James Schamus, Kitty Green and Scott Macaulay
start.headline_credit: Australia and United States of America, 2017
start.brief_description: Twenty years after the modern world’s most notorious child murder, the legacy of the crime and its impact are explored.

constellations_primary.name: Dial M for Media
constellations_primary.description: Explores the nature of media use in high-profile cases as well as the ability of media to sway public minds.

end.title: Evil Angels
end.creator_credit: Verity Lambert
end.headline_credit: Australia and United States of America, 1988
end.brief_description: Based on the true story of Lindy Chamberlain who, during a family camping trip to Ayers Rock in central Australia, claimed she witnessed a dingo take her baby daughter, Azaria, from their tent. Azaria’s body was never found and, after investigations and two public inquests, she is charged with murder.

constellations_other.name: Dial M for Media
constellations_other.description: Explores the nature of media use in high-profile cases as well as the ability of media to sway public minds.

links.description:
Kitty Green has stated that the “subject matter [she loves] to explore is women and their representation in the media.” Patsy Ramsey was highly criticised in the media for her behaviour post death of her daughter with many outlets posturing that she had murdered her own daughter due to jealousy.

Similarly, in the death of Azaria Chamberlain, the case on which Evil Angels is based, Lindy Chamberlain, was accused of murdering her daughter and the media greatly sensationalised her guilt and non “stereotypical” behaviour post event.

constellations_other.description: Steampunk aesthetics, malevolent AI and cybernetic cops push the frontiers of imagination in this Constellation inspired by Dishonored 2.

constellations_other.name: Femme fatales to fembots
constellations_other.description: When women gain power, men get scared. You can see this in the mysterious, seductive and deadly femme fatale. Using her sexuality and intellect to manipulate, control and co-opt power, the femme fatale reflects prevailing attitudes to women.

end.brief_description: In the year 2029, the barriers of our world have been broken down by the net and cybernetics, leaving humans opens to brain-hacking. When a hacker known as ‘The Puppet Master’ begins involving meddling in politics, a group of cybernetically enhanced cops are called in.

links.description: Motoko, the cyborg protagonist in Ghost in the Shell, questions the nature of identity in an increasingly digital world, while the main antagonist in the film, The Puppet Master, is a form of sentient AI.

links.description: The Ghost in the Shell soundtrack was composed by Clint Mansell, who also contributed to the score for Mass Effect 3. AI and tech are vital to the Mass Effect world, with the series antagonists a mixed race of synthetic/organic starships.
